comments.commentBody: @TZ: "It's been done again and again and again" by whom exactly?  True enough, Mr. Smith has appeared in a couple of other such movies featuring interracial romances (i.e., Hancock with Charlize Theron and the one with Eva Mendes, the title of which I can't now recall).  For whatever reason, though, these movies remain cultural outliers as audiences don't get more than one or two of them over the course of a given year.  Oddly enough, such relationships are now far more commonplace on network television than they are in big-budgeted movies.
The cold war was an uneasy time for writers.

This is an appalling breach of trust that is so easily dismissed by those who will defend mrs. Clinton from any appearance or actuality of impropriety.
She knows better and has the intellectual capacity to comprehend the significance of her use of personal, undocumented communications.
Shame on her. Just another example of flagrant abuse.
A woman, for all her intellect, poise and presumed power, who should not be president for many reasons!

Maybe she'll pull a 'Hillary' and snatch defeat from the jaws of victory for her second try at her coronation.  She's sabotaging herself with dumb mistakes and comments and her seeming entitlement attitude is not helping either. It's not as though she has a whole ton of charisma to fall back on.  Nothing is for certain, let's see some real candidates and do this the right way, the democratic way.
Will the NSA & court be prostitute for the crimes they committed?

"purposeful neglect of the rules"

If it were anyone else, the NYT would have pointed out that she broke the law.
Nowhere does this article state that her emails were not under surveillance by national security. Just not part of the public (and therefore) political record.

Hillary left the State Department in Feb. of 2013. In June of 2013 Snowden started revealing the NSA's ability to read personal emails.  How many different people had access to her emails and was this a huge breach of security? Her purposeful neglect of the rules should be investigated fully. Can she be prosecuted for jeopardizing national security?
Neither Bush nor Cheney, like Bill Clinton before them, used email while serving in office.
where is the solution?

Really? emails? then I'd say you were never interested in her potential choices for Supreme Court replacements if that comes up. Because, that's the only real difference between the parties these days.
I wasn't going to vote for her, but now I might. This is a game changer.
Mrs. Clinton was never my favorite candidate, but I probably would have voted for her. This is a game changer.
"For every complex problem there is an answer that is clear, simple, ...and wrong." - H. L. Menchken

How can we be outraged about crimes against humanity if there are no moral truths? Because the majority of our society shares certain opinions: for example, that killing is wrong. These beliefs, however, are not universal beliefs. Islamist radicals believe it is virtuous to kill heretical cartoonists, and Americans believe (for the most part) that it is acceptable to kill Islamist radicals and to execute murderers. Some believe that it is acceptable to kill fetuses prior to viability, others consider it a grave sin. Many vegetarians believe it is unethical to kill animals for food. So in general we think killing is wrong, but in the specifics we are all over the map.

If we are to believe that there are moral truths, perhaps someone could name just one that is universally accepted. Slavery is wrong? It was practiced here less than 200 years ago, and widely accepted. Jesus himself did not condemn it. Stealing is wrong? That makes it hard to explain all the wars of conquest that have been fought throughout history. Genocide is wrong? Yet it has taken place throughout history when groups battle over limited resources. There are many things we believe today, for example, about what marriage is and what is acceptable sexual behavior, that will probably be seen in the future as unfathomable, just as (most of us) look back at racial segregation.

It is disturbing to some, but there are no absolute moral truths. The best we can do is attempt a consensus based on current beliefs.
Please don't tarnish our memories of the esteemed Mr. Kadiddlehopper!
Except there is no conspiracy theory.  There is only actually acknowledging what the Clintons actually do and how they do it, something most of the drooling masses choose to ignore.

Well, it's like this.  The reason these emails are to be retained is that they are government records created on government time.  They are needed for oversight and for history.  Mrs. Clinton decided to evade potential FOIA reruests by playing her own game.

The article is quite clear that she used her personal account exclusively for 4 years.  So one of two things must be true: Either (a) Hillary, as Secretary of State,  sent no secret or important emails for 4 years, or (b) she sent such emails thru an unsecure, personal account.

On a purely logical plane, the notion that Clinton used her personal email account to send "secure mail" (by which I suspect you mean "mail that should have been secure") certainly doesn't follow from the fact of her having used a personal email account to send official communications. But since we know she used her personal account exclusively during her tenure at the State Department, not to have sent such sensitive communications through her personal account requires that in the four years she served as Secretary of State, she never sent an email that should have been secure. How likely is that?

Do people actually believe that just because she used personal email it follows that she sent secure mail via such?

You can tell just how afraid the other side is of Senator, Secretary of State and future President Clinton that they will jump all over any possible issue like excitable monkeys at a zoo.

I'm sure the POTUS was on the other end of many of her emails. Why wouldn't he say something to her about the impropriety of her email protocol? If I sent emails to everyone in my company only from a private account, there would be whistleblowers saying something to our auditors.

Memo for "C" in Hell's Kitchen:

Mike Bloomberg is not the one running for president, or did you not get the memo?

I fail to understand how the author disagrees with the worksheet examples of opinions. These examples are important for teaching children that there is a difference between opinion and fact. Trying to introduce too much nuance at that level is probably ill-advised. However, you might also explain that when someone supports their opinion with relevant facts, they can sometimes convince others to agree with their opinion. Once they move onto science classes, they'll learn what a hypothesis and a theory is -- another concept that the author struggles with. If the author, other philosophy professors, or parents need help teaching children the difference between fact and opinion, here are the given examples of opinions with facts underneath:

Opinion — Copying homework assignments is wrong.
Fact -- Copying homework assignments compromises the educational evaluation system by giving credit to students who did not complete the work as intended.

Opinion — It is wrong for people under the age of 21 to drink alcohol.
Fact: It is illegal for students under the age of 21 to drink alcohol.

Opinion — Vegetarians are healthier than people who eat meat.
Fact: There is some evidence to suggest that vegetarianism has positive health benefits.

Opinion: Majoring in Philosophy is a waste of time and money.
Fact: That last opinion wasn't in the original article. That was just for fun.

Can't we get someone else to run for president? This is just outrageous behavior in a public official. Is she going to conduct military business from her personal account? Maybe accidentally email the attack plans to a college pal? I will hold my nose and vote for her if she is all there is, but please, can't we get a choice?
I like the back-and-forth of the author's participation in the comments.  And I don't really recall any of the defensive nature, or at least they didn't strike me as inappropriate.

No, Remember when the Secret Service made Mr. Obama stop using his Blackberry? Even if she had a department account, it is not really much more secure than a private account. Nor does it need to be. For secure communication, there is a separate set of truly secure systems which the government uses - most of which were put on Wikileaks by a DOD leaker.

It would be helpful if the story identified the source of the account, which the House Committee leaker, er, source, clearly had.
will she continue to use her well secured AOL account when elected President?
Casey L: You're right--but no one probably said anything because they knew they would be fired immediately. Remember the Clinton ethos: don't question or cross me.

Because being Mayor is quite different than being the head of State, where there are actually secrets, drafts, diplomacy and lives at risk.  The worst thing Bloomberg faced was alternate street parking and banning Big Gulps.

I agree with you that there are things she should have known as an attorney. There are also things she should know simply by having an ethical compass...which she does not have. Remember, she was an attorney when she was fired as a Watergate counsel for ethical violations. Hillary has gotten away with so many slimy things, and been given a pass when she is incompetent, that she believes she is entitled to ascend.
But as we just saw with the IRS, they do disappear until after elections.

So Rlanni, breaking the law is fine if the other person did it?

Really?
